arch:note.arch:string: At the end of excavation season, trench supervisors were expected to write a concise summary of the full season's activities in each trench. This summary was the first step in building the interpretation and archaeological narrative of each trench.

arch:internalDocument.arch:string:
Journal / Summary:F-20-2005-Summary

Final Trench Summary Year 2005 Season

Area F

Trench 20

June 22, 2005

M. Baldi

This will be a truncated report of this trench:

This trench was opened just west of F 1 and the same inquiries posted for F 19 apply to this trench and I will import some of it into this final summary:

! The concerns and questions we desire to answer by opening this trench have much to do with the thick layer of burnt material that can best be observed on the West and East baulks of F 1. This ash layer is especially pronounced on the West baulk of F 1 and one of our questions deals with how far west it extends. Of course there are several layers of interest that need to be documented for better context and to complement that which was found and collected as F 1 was excavated.

The trench was "haphazardly" laid as a 5.5 meter long by 4.75 meter wide of excavation area; baulks are not counted as part of the trench. The two trenches (F 1 and F 20) are adjoining and we have no separation between them; we will remove the area between the two trenches joining them together as we go. Having the baulks of F 1 to work from is very helpful and will allow us to speed things up. After the trench was marked at the end of May 29th we had asked some of the workers to return that afternoon but they were unable to, so we began clearing the area today and started work with big picks in hopes to get past the cobble surface already documented in F 19. We have been interested on the extent of the lower town at Kenan Tepe and its relationship to the main mound perhaps as an outlaying commercial or production area. We also have questions about the possible causes for the thick burnt ashy layer and its extent on this side of the lower area. Was this a production plant that burned down, or was it perhaps a single burned house. Of interest also is finding the reasons for the apparently extensive conflagration; was it an accident? or was it intentionally burned down by an invading group. Being this close to the river, this area would have been one of the first areas to suffer invasion and destruction.

The excavations on this trench were done sporadically as two other trenches were also occupying my time. After having gone through several of the upper layers we encountered the same cobble surface that we did in F 19.

That are a lot of good possibilities for this trench, initially after having dug a pit and the cobble surfaces we began encountering walls and this is where the trench was left.

The area of the trench was subdivided to include the larger general areas where the red bricky soft soil was removed. The other area is a narrow stepped up area abutting the south wall which presents the idea of being a wall, but more articulation is necessary before it is more clearly identified. This may be a short wall going west, but the real possibility exists on whether it extends south to join up with large wall found in F 22.

The thick layer of the red soil (in some areas as much as .60 meters) does seem to have expanded throughout most of the trench. The east end of the trench presents a collapsed brick (south towards north) formation possibly sitting on to of a surface.

A floor and baulk area on the northeast quadrant display a quantity of burned brick but mostly fragments were found. It is unclear where in a possible structure this oven or fireplace may have stood, or what relation it had to any structure.

On closing the trench I assigned Loci numbers to particular features that next seasonâ€™s excavator can continue:

Locus 11 the wide wall near the East end of the trench and next to the ashy layer. This wall may expand into F 22. of interest is the little niche cut into it from L 14

Locus 22 is the wall marked by some rocks near the west end. It may be the small wall with bricks in between, this is a similar feature as the one found in F 22. there are actually two small walls with brick in between laying on their side.

Locus 13 there may be a rounded wall. Unsure of it at this time. It may be a lining for a pit.

Locus 14 ash layer on east wall

Locus 15 was dug last day and it appeared that a whole jar was recovered in pieces.
